questions.text: A 1-month-old girl is brought to the physician because her mother has noticed that the girl's head is always tilted to the right. She was delivered at term, and childbirth was complicated by a breech position. There is no family history of serious illness. She appears healthy. She is at 60th percentile for length and weight. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 102/min, and respirations are 42/min. Examination shows the head tilted toward the right, and the chin rotated towards the left. Range of motion of the neck is limited. There is a palpable, firm, well-circumscribed mass in the right lower side of the neck. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the neck can help to clarify an undefined neck mass (e.g., retropharyngeal abscess), predict potential malignancy, and reveal a tumor's extent and location. However, the location of this patient's neck mass, history of intrauterine breeching position, tilted/rotated head, and restricted range of motion are classic features for a specific diagnosis that does not require CT imaging.

B) INCORRECT:

Botulinum toxin injection is an experimental second-line treatment for congenital torticollis. Although a few studies suggest that botulinum toxin may be beneficial, its efficacy is not yet confirmed.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is consistent with congenital torticollis, which typically manifests with a tilted head toward the affected side, rotation of the chin towards the opposite side, and a limited range of motion of the neck. A palpable, well-circumscribed mass within the sternocleidomastoid muscle (SCM) due to fibrosis is also common. Ultrasound of the SCM can confirm the muscular origin of the mass. First-line treatment of congenital torticollis involves early initiation of physiotherapy with positioning exercises and passive stretching therapy to strengthen neck muscles, lengthen the SCM, and improve the cervical range of motion. The majority of cases of congenital torticollis resolve after 2–6 months of conservative management. In patients who do not improve after 12 months of conservative management, surgery (e.g., myotomy) is indicated to prevent complications such as cervical scoliosis and/or craniofacial asymmetry.
Image Description:

Congenital muscular torticollis (CMT) is caused by fibrosis and/or contraction of a sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle, resulting in neck flexion toward the affected SCM and chin rotation toward the opposite side. Physical examination typically shows limited passive range of motion (limited rotation and flexion of the neck). If untreated, CMT can result in craniofacial asymmetry.

D) INCORRECT:

An x-ray of the cervical spine is indicated for suspected cervical trauma, atlantoaxial joint lesions, and other congenital bony anomalies (e.g., hemivertebrae, congenital scoliosis) that can lead to a rotated head position. Cervical spine injury during birth is very rare and would present with further symptoms such as neck pain and tenderness. Although this patient has a twisted and rotated head, she shows no signs of an acute injury and no symptoms of associated anomalies in other organ systems that are common in patients with congenital bony anomalies.

E) INCORRECT:

Fine needle aspiration (FNA) is indicated for neck masses that suggest pathologies such as lymphoma, thyroid cancer, salivary gland neoplasms, inflammatory lymphadenopathy, or metastases. If history and physical examination are inconclusive, FNA is indicated to exclude malignant conditions that require treatment. While this patient has a solitary neck mass, she lacks signs of infection (e.g., fever, painful lymph nodes, upper respiratory tract infection) that could have caused reactive lymphadenopathy. Signs of malignancy (e.g., fatigue, unexplained fever, night sweats, and/or weight loss) are also absent. Instead, this patient's head position suggests a diagnosis that does not require FNA.

F) INCORRECT:

A surgical approach (e.g., myotomy or bipolar release of the SCM) is only indicated in patients with congenital muscular torticollis who have failed 12 months of conservative management. However, more than 90% of children improve after 2–6 months of conservative therapy and do not require surgery. Since this patient has not yet received conservative treatment, a myotomy is not indicated.
questions.hint: The firm mass is within the sternocleidomastoid muscle.

questions.text: A 3-week-old male infant is brought to the physician by his parents because they noticed that his head has been tilted to the left since birth. Physical examination shows the head turned toward the left side and the chin rotated toward the right. He cries during an attempt to rotate the head to the right. There is a firm, well-circumscribed mass on the left lower side of the neck. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Decreased intrauterine space during pregnancy (e.g., due to fetal macrosomia, multiple gestation, oligohydramnios) is a risk factor for the development of torticollis as it may lead to fetal malpositioning and/or decreased intrauterine fetal movement. In addition, fetal macrosomia, breech presentation, and assisted vaginal delivery can cause perinatal trauma to the sternocleidomastoid muscles, which is another risk factor for the development of congenital torticollis.

B) INCORRECT:

Cesarean delivery is not a proven risk factor for the development of congenital torticollis. C-section is less likely than assisted vaginal delivery to cause traction to the neonate's neck, which is a known risk factor for congenital torticollis.

C) INCORRECT:

Vertex presentation is the most common form of cephalic presentation; it is not a predisposing factor for the development of congenital torticollis. However, breech presentation may lead to congenital torticollis as it has a higher risk of perinatal trauma to the sternocleidomastoid muscles during delivery than a vertex presentation.

D) INCORRECT:

Dopamine receptor antagonists such as haloperidol can cause acute dystonia, which manifests with torticollis if the sternocleidomastoid muscle is involved. However, dystonic torticollis does not manifest with a palpable mass in the sternocleidomastoid muscle, as seen in this infant.

E) INCORRECT:

Polyhydramnios increases intrauterine space; it is not a predisposing factor for the development of congenital torticollis. Oligohydramnios, however, may cause congenital torticollis due to intrauterine restriction of the fetus.

F) INCORRECT:

Preterm birth is not a direct risk factor for the development of congenital torticollis. Conditions associated with preterm birth include neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, retinopathy of prematurity, necrotizing enterocolitis, persistent fetal circulation, intracranial hemorrhage, and sepsis.
questions.hint: This newborn's head tilt, limited passive range of motion of the neck, and palpable lower neck mass are consistent with a diagnosis of congenital torticollis. The mass seen here is the shortened, thickened segment of the sternocleidomastoid muscle that was injured in-utero or during delivery.
